abstract_summ: We anticipate that the state Kerala, with one of the highest cases of COVID-19, may not receive significant incoming cases, while Karnataka and Haryana may receive the challenge of high incoming cases, with medium cases so far.Methods: Here, in collaboration with Facebook Data for Good, we built metapopulation models that incorporate human movement data with the goals of identifying the high risk areas of disease spread and assessing the potential effects of local travel restrictions in Taiwan.Our results highlight how human mobility can affect the epidemic, identifying particular situations in which the health authorities can promptly intervene to control the disease spread.In India, the mobility towards professional sites can surge incoming cases at Maharastra and Karnataka, while migration towards the native places can risk Uttar Pradesh and Bihar.India is a large country, with a highly variable inter-state mobility, and dynamically varying infection cases in different locations; thus, the existing models, based solely on the aspects of growth rates, or generalized network concepts, may not provide desired predictions.
title_summ: Mobility network modeling explains higher SARS-CoV-2 infection rates among disadvantaged groups and informs reopening strategiesModeling the impact of human mobility and travel restrictions on the potential spread of SARS-CoV-2 in TaiwanBetween Geography and Demography: Key Interdependencies and Exit Mechanisms for Covid-19Modeling geographical spread of COVID-19 in India using network-based approachPotential dissemination of epidemics based on Brazilian mobile geolocation data.Part I: Population dynamics and future spreading of infection in the states of Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro during the pandemic of COVID-19.Effects of mobility and multi-seeding on the propagation of the COVID-19 in SpainDisparate Patterns of Movements and Visits to Points of Interests Located in Urban Hotspots across U.S. Metropolitan Cities during COVID-19Time, Space and Social Interactions: Exit Mechanisms for the Covid-19 EpidemicsSpatial super-spreaders and super-susceptibles in human movement networksThe effect of interurban movements on the spatial distribution of population in ChinaExploring the roles of high-speed train, air and coach services in the spread of COVID-19 in ChinaA municipality-based approach using commuting census data to characterise the vulnerability to influenza-like epidemic: the COVID-19 application in Italy.Mapping the Port Influence Diffusion Patterns: A Case Study of Rotterdam, Antwerp and SingaporeAMunicipality-Based Approach Using Commuting Census Data to Characterize the Vulnerability to Influenza-Like Epidemic:
title_abstract_phrases: Methods: Here, in collaboration with Facebook Data for Good, we built metapopulation models that incorporate human movement data with the goals of identifying the high risk areas of disease spread and assessing the potential effects of local travel restrictions in Taiwan.Our results highlight how human mobility can affect the epidemic, identifying particular situations in which the health authorities can promptly intervene to control the disease spread.We anticipate that the state Kerala, with one of the highest cases of COVID-19, may not receive significant incoming cases, while Karnataka and Haryana may receive the challenge of high incoming cases, with medium cases so far.In India, the mobility towards professional sites can surge incoming cases at Maharastra and Karnataka, while migration towards the native places can risk Uttar Pradesh and Bihar.India is a large country, with a highly variable inter-state mobility, and dynamically varying infection cases in different locations; thus, the existing models, based solely on the aspects of growth rates, or generalized network concepts, may not provide desired predictions.
